items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling slowly on the River Pang. However, flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible, especially in areas close to the river around Tidmarsh due to high groundwater levels. The beginning of the week is expected to be mainly dry, with some bands of rain and isolated showers possible towards the end of the week. We expect river levels to continue to gradually fall, but levels will be sensitive to rainfall. 
Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated on Monday morning, 31/03/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tyne and Wear coast

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
Coastal conditions are expected to improve this evening and no flooding is expected.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

items.description: The Suffolk coast at Southwold
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides, however this set of spring tides will remain high for the next few days. We do not expect to issue any further alerts or warnings. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.64 mAOD at 17:15 on 31/03/25 and 4.66 mAOD at 05:15 on 01/04/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 54 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 01/04/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Monday's early morning tide at 01:15 on 31/03/2025 is higher than normal, with light Northerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.22 m. The total forecast tide is 6.32 metres Chart Datum (3.27 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Monday afternoon's tide at 13:30 on 31/03/2025 is forecast to be 38 cm lower (2.89 mAOD). Flood impacts could return again on Tuesday 1st April. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 18:00 on 31/03/2025.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington
Thorney Island to West Itchenor
items.message: The high spring tides which brought elevated water levels along the coast have now passed. Monday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 31/03/2025 is forecast to be lower than recent days and accompanied by light South Easterly Force 3 winds. The weather decreases tide table values by -0.1 m. The total forecast tide is 4.99 metres Chart Datum (2.25 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. Over the next five days, light winds and small waves are forecast, and with tides lower, no more than minimal flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if property flooding could be possible.

items.description: Tidal areas of Littlehampton Rope Walk
items.message: The high spring tides which brought elevated water levels along the coast have now passed. Monday afternoon's tide at 12:30 on 31/03/2025 is forecast to be lower than recent days and accompanied by light South Easterly Force 3 winds. The weather decreases tide table values by -0.1 m. The total forecast tide is 5.93 metres Chart Datum (2.88 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Over the next five days, light winds and small waves are forecast, and with tides lower, no more than minimal flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if property flooding could be possible.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Gribbin Head to Rame Head
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Monday morning.  High water at Plymouth is at 07:57 am, times of high water will vary along the coast. 
 
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Plymouth is 2.72 mAOD. Expect tide levels along the coast to vary only slightly due to calm conditions and high pressure. 
 
 
Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas including Fore Street, Town Quay, Albert Quay and Caffa Mill Car park at Fowey, Quay Street and Recreation ground at Lostwithiel, Polperro Harbour, Quay Road and The Quay at Looe and the B3247 at Seaton 
 
Do not walk or drive through flood water or waves.   
  
We are monitoring the situation and will update this information if the situation changes.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding the Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Falmouth is 2.74 mAOD. Expect tide levels along the coast to vary only slightly due to calm conditions and high pressure. 
 
Locations particularly at risk include low lying coastal communities including Cadgwith and Coverack, Porthallow, the tidal Helford Estuary, Maenporth and Swanpool, St.Mawes, East Portholland, Gorran Haven,  Portmellon, Mevagissey, Pentewan and Par 
 
Do not walk or drive through flood water or waves.   


We are monitoring the situation and will update this information if the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is possible for a few hours either side of high water at 9:15 PM on 30/03/2025 and 9:30 AM om 31/03/2025
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
We have closed flood gates at Pill.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth. The first forecast high water is at 9:15 PM on 30/03/2025 with a level of 7.67 mAODN with north-westerly force 4 winds.  The second forecast tide is at 9:30 AM on 31/03/2025 with a level of 7.94 mAOD with north-easterly force 2 winds.  This Flood Alert is likely to be in force until Tuesday 1st April.
This message will be updated in the afternoon of 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding remains possible for this afternoons high tide, Sunday 30th March, and tomorrow mornings high tide, Monday 31st March. High water at Ilfracombe is at 19:45 BST this afternoon and 08:15 BST tomorrow morning, times of high water will vary along the coast.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast this afternoon, 31/03/2025.

Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 14:00 BSTon 31/03/2025 at the following locations: 

Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 14:30 BST 

Eastford Road, peaking around 14:30 BST

Arpley Bridge, peaking around 14:45 BST

Knutsford Rd, peaking around 14:45 BST

Howley, peaking around 15:00 BST

It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.
 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities

This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
High tides are expected from Monday 31st March through to Wednesday 2nd April which may cause flooding to low lying areas along the coast. Todays lunchtime tide being the highest of this tide cycle.

This flood alert covers the high tide between 12:30 BST on 31/03/2025 and 14:30 BST on 31/03/2025, with the highest tide level expected around 13:30 BST. 

Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale.

We are monitoring the situation and we are closing flood gates, where needed. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.

This message will be updated by 5PM on 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Gretna to Silloth

This Flood Alert is for the lunchtime tide between 12:30 BST on 31/03/2025 and 14:30 BST on 31/03/2025, with the highest level expected around 13:30 BST 31/03/2025.

Areas most at risk include Coastline from Gretna to Silloth.

We are monitoring the situation and we are closing flood gates, where needed. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
High tides from 31 March 2025 may lead to flooding. This flood alert covers the high tide at 13:15 BST on 31/03/2025 with further detail as follows;

Date of FA Threshold being met : 31/03/2025
Time of FA Threshold being met : 12:45 BST
Duration of FA Threshold being exceeded: 15 mins 
Peak Water Level: 5.40mAOD
Time of Peak Water Level: 13:15- 13:30 BST
Time of High Astronomical Tide (tide table): 13:24 BST
High Astronomical Tide Level (tide table): 5.33mAOD
Wind Direction: SW
Wind Speed: Force 2


Subsequent high tides up to and including the mid day high tide on 01/04/2025 are expected to reach the Flood Alert level.  This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message:

Date of FA Threshold being met : 31/03/2025
Time of FA Threshold being met : 12:45 BST
Duration of FA Threshold being exceeded: 15 mins 
Peak Water Level: 5.65mAOD
Time of Peak Water Level: 13:15 BST
Time of High Astronomical Tide (tide table): 13:24 BST
High Astronomical Tide Level (tide table): 5.33mAOD
Wind Direction: SW
Wind Speed: Force 2

The thresholds set at Glasson Dock are not forecast to be reached in this set of Spring Tides. The maximum level forecast to be reached is 5.68mAOD at 13:30 BST on 31/03/25. This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 31/03/25 or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Hornsea

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: High tides and strong winds are expected to cause flooding between 6:15pm and 8.30pm today, Monday 31/03/2025. Flooding is expected to affect areas on Marine Drive, along South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Consider enacting your flood plan. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message by 5:30pm, Monday 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: High tides and strong winds are expected to cause flooding from overtopping waves and wind-blown spray between 6:15pm and 8.30pm today, Monday 31/03/2025. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, especially at exposed areas of the coast. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Skipsea to Mappleton, including Hornsea. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and spray could be dangerous. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9pm Monday 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: High tides and strong winds are expected to cause flooding from overtopping waves and wind-blown spray between 6:30pm and 9:45pm today, Monday 31/03/2025. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, especially at exposed areas of the coast. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point, including Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and spray could be dangerous. Further flooding is possible over the next few days due to high spring tides. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9:00PM Monday 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a series of high spring tides are expected for 3 days. Commencing with the high tide on Sunday morning 30/03/2025, flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations that may be affected include areas river side of defences where defences are present including Lydney Harbour. Low lying land at Purton on the east bank may also be impacted. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary.
Predicted peaks. Sharpness 10.0m to 10.2m at 21:45 on 30/03/2025 and 10.2m to 10.4m at 10:00 on 31/03/2025.
Flooding is not forecast at other gauge sites.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
This Alert remains in force for the high tide at 5:45 PM on Monday 31st March.

High spring tides accompanied by strong winds and waves mean flooding is possible at Newcastle Quayside around the high tide between 4:45 PM and 7:45 PM on Monday 31/03/2025.

Areas most at risk are coastal roads and footpaths with the potential for some minor overtopping near the Swing Bridge at Newcastle Quayside. We are working closely with Newcastle City Council to ensure that any sandbagging requirements are in place though levels are not expected to be as high as those seen on Sunday afternoon 30/03/2025.  

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Detailed tidal information for those that use it; The forecast high tide level is 3.10mAOD.

This message will be updated by 8:00 PM on Monday 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

Do not walk or drive through flood water or waves.

items.description: Somerset coast at Minehead, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea and Uphill to Kingston Seymour
items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, but property flooding is not expected.
Highest tide level is expected to be at coastal areas at Minehead, Combwich, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea, Uphill, Weston-super-Mare, Kewstoke, Sand Bay and Kingston Seymour at 9:00 AM on Monday 31/03/2025. Flooding is possible for up to an hour either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include coastal areas at Minehead, Combwich, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea, Uphill, Weston-super-Mare, Kewstoke, Sand Bay and Kingston Seymour.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinkley Point of 6.78 mAODN at 9:00 AM on 31/03/2025, with north-easterly force 2 winds. mAODN is height above average sea level.
All times are to British Summer Time.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Clevedon
items.message:
High tides tomorrow, Monday, morning may lead to flooding of roads and low lying land, but property flooding is not expected.
Highest tide level is expected to be at the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade at 9:30 AM on Monday 31/03/2025. Flooding is possible for up to an hour either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 7.93 mAODN at 9:30 AM on Monday 31/03/2025, which is 0.15 m above tide tables, with north easterly force 2 winds. mAODN is height above average sea level.
All times are to British Summer Time.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal flooding near the South Humber Bank from Barton Upon Humber to Humberston

floodArea.county: Lincolnshire, North East Lincolnshire, North Lincolnshire

items.message: Stormy conditions are forecast, resulting in a tidal surge moving down the East Coast of England on Sunday evening. This will lead to unusually high tidal levels along the South Humber Bank from Barton on Humber to Humberstone. The time and date of the forecast high water is 19:15 on 30 March 2025, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. The high tides combined with strong winds may result in wind-blown spray and wave splash causing localised pooling of water behind the sea defences.  Low lying coastal land and roads will be affected first.  Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring tide levels, and have staff in the field checking our defences and closing tidal gates where required. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths near beaches or promenades and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, as sea spray and waves could be dangerous. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal flooding near the South Humber Bank from Whitton to South Ferriby
items.message: Stormy conditions are forecast, resulting in a tidal surge moving down the East Coast of England on Sunday evening. This will lead to unusually high tidal levels along The South Humber Bank, between Whitton and South Ferriby. The time and date of the forecast high water is 19:15 on 30 March 2025, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of this. The high tides combined with strong winds may result in wind-blown spray and wave splash may cause localised pooling of water behind the sea defences. If conditions deteriorate, the A1077 flood gate across the A1077 may be closed. A further message will be issued if this becomes apparent. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn’t likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring tide levels, and have staff in the field checking our defences and closing tidal gates where required. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths and roads, as sea spray and waves can be dangerous. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides, however this set of spring tides will remain high for the next few days. We do not expect to issue any further alerts or warnings. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
The Flood Alert for this area has now been removed. 
According to the current forecast, tidal conditions should not require an Alert over the next 24 hours. There may be further tides beyond that, which require this tidal Alert to be sent out again.
We continue to monitor the situation and will issue further Alerts if necessary. Please continue to be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.

items.description: North Sea and River Esk at Whitby Harbour
Coast from Silloth to St Bees
items.message:
High tides are expected from Monday 31st March through to Wednesday 2nd April which may cause flooding to low lying areas along the coast. Todays lunchtime tide is the Peak of this tide cycle.

This Flood Alert is for the lunchtime tide between 12:30 BST on 31/03/2025 and 14:30 BST on 31/03/2025, with the highest level expected around 13:30 BST 31/03/2025.

Areas most at risk include Low lying areas along the coast from Silloth to St Bees Head including Allonby, Maryport, Flimby, Workington, Parton and Whitehaven.

We are monitoring the situation and we are closing flood gates, where needed. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.

This message will be updated by 5PM on 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent at Alkborough Flats
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Blacktoft river gauge as a result of high spring tides. Consequently, flooding of property is imminent.  Areas most at risk are the Alkborough Flats. The Blacktoft river gauge is forecast to overtop the lower and upper spillways and result in flooding.   

We expect river levels to remain high until after this evenings high tide.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.  

To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 31/03/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Dee Estuary from Parkgate to Chester
items.message:

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

The previous tide of concern overnight has now passed,  the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on promenades and coastal footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Lambourn and its tributaries from Upper Lambourn down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Lambourn, Great Shefford Stream, Winterbourne Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high, but are falling slowly, on the Winterbourne Stream and the River Lambourn due to high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Bagnor area. The beginning of the week is expected to be mainly dry, with some bands of rain and isolated showers possible towards the end of the week. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days. Levels will be sensitive to further rainfall.
Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated on Monday morning, 31/03/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Medway
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding as future high tides are expected to reduce significantly.
Tidal conditions are expected to improve this morning and no further flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message: Groundwater levels are slowly falling, but remain over the flood alert thresholds. Areas at risk include areas around the Till and the Wylye Valley. Flooding of roads and fields is possible. There is no significant rainfall forecast this week. We are not currently expecting very much drop in the groundwater levels. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 02/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but are falling slowly, at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but are falling slowly, at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley.  Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels, in the Candovers and Old Alresford, are high but continue to slowly fall. In the last week, the level at Preston Candover has fallen by 8cm. At Old Alresford, the level has fallen by 10cm. A small number of properties are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding in Preston Candover and Old Alresford. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively. From today (24/03/2025) to Friday (28/03/2025), the weather is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels will continue to slowly fall and flooding impacts will decrease. Flood impacts are expected to continue well into April. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 31/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Flamstead
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 2nd April 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 2nd April 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but are falling slowly, at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained rainfall. Low-lying land and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels are high, but continue to slowly fall. In the last week, the level has fallen by 19cm. We expect much of the village to experiencing cellar flooding and impacts to the sewerage system. From today (24/03/2025) to Friday (28/03/2025), the weather is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels will continue to slowly fall and flooding impacts will decrease. Flooding impacts are expected to continue into April. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 31/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels, in the villages surrounding Andover, are high but slowly falling. At Clanville, the level has fallen by 21cm in the last week. Cellar flooding impacts may be ongoing in Appleshaw, Hatherden and Penton Grafton. Groundwater is likely to be affecting Deacon and Down Road, Kimpton as well as the main road into Penton Grafton. Impacts to the sewerage system in Penton Mewsey and Appleshaw are ongoing. From today (24/03/2025) to Friday (28/03/2025), the weather is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels will continue to slowly fall, and flooding impacts will decrease. If the weather forecast is favourable next week, this Flood Alert will be removed. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 31/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe are high, but continue to slowly fall. In the last week, the level at Oakley, has fallen by 13cm. In Deane, we expect cellar flooding impacts to be ongoing. Groundwater will be affecting the ability of septic tanks to operate effectively. From today (24/03/2025) to Friday (28/03/2025), the weather is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels will continue to slowly fall, and flooding impacts will decrease. Flooding impacts are expected to continue into April. We continue to monitor the level and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 31/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Henley and Assendon area
items.message: Groundwater levels remain high at our Stonor borehole near Henley and Assendon. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low lying land, roads and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mimram in Hertfordshire
items.message:
Flooding is affecting low lying land, roads and gardens close to the River Mimram. This is due to persistent rainfall in December and January which has led to high groundwater levels. 

We are monitoring the flooding that is currently affecting the Fulling Mill Lane, Singlers Marsh, and Codicote Road areas in Welwyn. 

There is elevated risk of flooding caused by water emerging from a third party blocked culvert. Flooding to homes and businesses is unlikely at this time, but there may be a risk to very low-lying properties or those with basements. River levels in other areas remain below levels of concern. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are continuing to monitor the situation.

This message will be updated by 5pm, Wednesday 2nd April 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Leckhampstead area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but falling slowly, at our Chapel Wood borehole in the Leckhampstead area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low lying land, roads and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

items.description: Bosham and West Itchenor
items.message: The high spring tides which brought elevated water levels along the coast have now passed. Monday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 31/03/2025 is forecast to be lower than recent days and accompanied by light South Easterly Force 3 winds. The weather decreases tide table values by -0.1 m. The total forecast tide is 4.99 metres Chart Datum (2.25 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. Over the next five days, light winds and small waves are forecast, and with tides lower, no more than minor flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Warning if new instances of property flooding are expected.
